addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

30 Januar
ie
1588
From M
r
Bodley.
The
states
obstinancie, especially of
Barnevelt
seeming to be alienat from any good concept of her
M
ts
doinges.

page.lettertext:
xxx
[.]
Januarij
1588
It may please yo
r
H. I have heerew
t
sent
e copie of
that whiche I delvered
e States General, uppon her Ma
ties
Instructions: also their Answear, and my Replie againe
wherin I have used
M
r
Gilpins
assistance, by whose ad-
vise, as likewise by
M
r
Killiegrewes
, I did alter and
adde some pointes, to drawe them on to a better accepta-
tion. But I doe finde them very stiffe, wheresoever
Barnevelt
they settle: especially Barnevelt, who, as I suspect,
doth continewe in his wonted alienation,
for any good
conceat of her Ma
ties
proceedinges.
I have dealt w
t
him privatly and publickly, and I have offered my
extraordinarie travell, for effecting some demandes
But it seemeth by his speeches, and by
e cariage
of himself, that he hath litle confidence in any promis
e
that we make. The answear
at I send was of h
is
own penning, and savoureth altogether of his ordi-
narie phrase, whiche is somewhat violent, imperious,
and bitter. I hope my replie therunto will stand w
t
yo
r
H. good liking, considering there is nothing sett
downe, to prejudice suche further answear, as her
Ma
tie
shall send hither. I am urged by the
the number in the
cautionarye townes
to be lessened
counsell,
and somwhat angerly somtimes, about
e
reducing of
e Cautionary townes, to
e number by
contract: Wherto I make no other answear, but
at
it was her Hig
nes
resoluc
o
n, and so doth continewe,
unles their backwardnes, in graunting her peti-
tions shall occasion
e contrary. I can
Deventer
not use more inducements unto them for
e releas-
Leyden
ment of Deventer, and
e restituc
o
n of those of Leiden,
Aisma
e President Aisma &c then I have done already.
But I see
at almost
e very names of those per-
sons are odious unto them: of Deventer in speciall:
whose very best frindes have almost given over, to
solicite his deliverance. For
ei finde it almost in vaine,
for
e c
o
mon opinion that goeth of him, that being sett
at liberty, he will worke his revenge, by sinister practise,
ether in
England,
or els where against these Provinces.
Moreover I have bin openly answeared at
e Councel table
fol.187v
that since my c
o
ming hither, and her Ma
ties
last writing,
he hath braved
e Magistrats of
Utrecht,
w
t
so muche
insolence, as they could not disgest it. They have lately
charged him againe w
t
newe articles, and restrained
him of his former liberty in prison. I doe partly see
by
e humo
r
of his letters, that his owne vaine glory,
doth hurt him very muche, and doth make him advise
his frindes to suche courses in his behalf, as would turne
in
e end to their discredit, and no good to himself.
Nevertheles, for that I knowe it is her Ma
ties
pleasure
I doe not give over, to practise his enlargem
t
. He
writeth very often unto me, and this day he req
e
sted me
by letter to write once againe to
e
Count de Meurs
,
w
ch
I have done to suche purpose, as himself hath re-
quested. Likewise for
Saravia,
and
e rest
Saravia
of Leiden,
Frise
&c. I can get no other answear, then
that w
ch
is in writing. As yet I shall not be
able to lett yo
r
H. Understand, howe well this people shall
have meanes, to continewe their contributiones, w
at
assistaunce they will yeld, for
e protection of any
place, that shall be offered in
e revolted Provinces,
Who they are among
e Principals heere, that stand
best affected to her Ma
tie
. Nether can I satisfie those
privat
other
demandes, w
ch
I receaved further of yo
r
H.
in a privat Memorial. For if I should speak uppon
mine owne judgement, and not uppon report or opinion
of others, it will require some longer continuance and
triall of their actions. I have moved
M
r
Gilpin
mony in
Ger:
about
e meanes, to take up mony for her Ma
tie
uppon
e marchants adventurers bandes, whiche he supposeth
may be done in sundrie places of Germany.
The last
at I receaved from yo
r
H. was of
e 27
of De
c
w
t
a letter from her Ma
tie
to
Scheincke
, w
ch
I
sent away by an expresse messenger, according to yo
r
H. direction, but
e messenger, albeit it be fourten
daies since, is not yet returned. I doe not
certifie yo
r
H. of
e particular proceedinges of di-
ers Provinces, because I knowe M
r
Gilpin doth it and
can doe it more effectually. For their consultac
o
ns are
fol.188r
commonly in Flemmishe, and likewise
e booke of their
recordes, whiche is alwaies in his handling. I finde
every day that
e states g
nr
all, and
e
states of Hol-
land
and
Zeland
proceede in writing and proposing
of most matters, aswell heere, as to her Ma
tie
w
t
out
e privitie of
e Councell of state: in w
ch
respect I
am to beseche yo
r
H. that whatsoever Letters, arti-
cles or proposals shalbe delivered by
Ortell,
or any
other their minister, if they shall concerne any mater
fitte to be imparted unto me, it may please yo
r
H. to
acquaint me w
t
it, for my better correspondence w
t
her Ma
ties
resoluc
o
ns. Concerning
e horsebandes
and footbandes, that should be sent for
Portugall
from
hence, because I have nothing therein in particular
charge, I am
e bolder to referre yo
r
H. to my
L.
G
nr
als
letters, and
S
r
Edward Norris
relation, whose
diligence, and discreete handling of maters in that
negotiation, I can
not
c
o
mend sufficiently to yo
r
H.
wher-
w
t
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
Ja
n
30. 88. Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
